article.title: Continuum Foreground Polarization and Na I Absorption in Type Ia SNe

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements about Figure 1 is **incorrect**?
choices: The left panel shows spectra of SNe that exhibit Na I D absorption lines at the redshift of their host galaxies.
The right panel shows spectra of SNe that do not exhibit Na I D absorption lines at the redshift of their host galaxies.
The intensity of the Na I D absorption lines is similar in all SNe shown in the left panel.
The position of the Na I D lines at the redshift of the SN hosts is indicated by arrows.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is generally observed in the continuum polarization spectra of SNe in the sodium sample (Figure 2) as the average polarization decreases?
choices: The slope of the polarization spectrum becomes steeper.
The slope of the polarization spectrum becomes shallower.
The wavelength of maximum polarization shifts to the blue.
The line polarization becomes more prominent.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 7 demonstrate about the wavelength of maximum polarization (λmax) for SNe in the sodium sample compared to Milky Way stars?
choices: The sodium sample SNe have, on average, shorter λmax than Milky Way stars.
The sodium sample SNe have, on average, longer λmax than Milky Way stars.
The sodium sample SNe have a similar distribution of λmax to Milky Way stars.
The non-sodium sample SNe have much shorter λmax than both the sodium sample and Milky Way stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Equation 2, how is the value of the "constant" K in the modified Serkowski law related to the wavelength of maximum polarization (λmax)?
choices: K is inversely proportional to λmax.
K is directly proportional to λmax.
K is a complex function of λmax that cannot be described by a simple relationship.
